Participants.evidence: Seventeen patients with epilepsy participated in an ECoG motor mapping experiment.

Intervention.evidence: The maps derived from GLM-based ECoG mapping, ECS, and fMRI were then compared.

Objective.evidence: In this study the authors aim to validate the clinical usage of high gamma activity in presurgical mapping by comparing ECoG mapping with traditional direct electrical cortical stimulation (ECS) and functional MRI (fMRI) mapping.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The high gamma activity on ECoG was modeled using the general linear model (GLM), and the regions showing significant gamma power increase during the task condition compared with the rest condition were localized.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Seventeen patients with epilepsy participated in an ECoG motor mapping experiment.

Result_Outcome.evidence: GLM-based ECoG mapping showed a significantly higher sensitivity than fMRI (66.7% for ECoG, 52.6% for fMRI, p < 0.05), while the specificity was high for both techniques (> 97%).
